questions.question_text: In the event table, which field maps the external attributes from the target system?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Same as other, opening the Alert Console will show the alert with following filter:
1. Role in group != Secondary (i.e. only Primary Alert)
2. State != Closed 
3. Severity != OK
4. Maintenance = false
Time to fix what it states is the correct answer, I truly hope individuals are reading these sections, D is the correct answer as noted below.

Selected Answer: D
D. All Primary, Open alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode
D, no secondary, maintenance or closed alerts are shown
D. All Primary, Open alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode

Selected Answer: D
https://<servicenow-instance>/nav_to.do?uri=%2F$sa_alerts_console_view

choices.A: All Primary, Open alerts and anomaly alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode
choices.D: All Primary, Open alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode
choices.B: All Primary and Secondary Open alerts and anomaly alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode
choices.C: All Primary alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, Warning that are not in Maintenance mode
choices.E: All Primary and Secondary Open alerts with a Severity of Critical, Major, Minor, and Warning that are not in Maintenance mode

questions.question_text: By default, the Alert Console displays what type of alerts?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDE
CDE are correct

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE are correct

The recommended best practices for Event Management are:

C. Filter out events at the source rather than in the ServiceNow instance.

Filtering events at the source reduces unnecessary noise and improves efficiency in the processing of events.
D. Base-line "normal-state" events to filter out background noise.

Establishing a baseline for normal events helps filter out background noise, making it easier to identify and prioritize abnormal or critical events.
E. Ignore all non-critical events during the initial implementation to streamline processing; add alerts over time as time and resources allow.
CDE are correct

Selected Answer: CDE
correct

questions.question_text: Which are recommended best practices for Event Management? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Promote all events to alerts during initial implementation until you fully understand which should be ignored.
choices.D: Base-line “normal-state” events to filter out background noise.
choices.E: Ignore all non-critical events during initial implementation to streamline processing; add alerts over time as time and resources allow.
choices.A: Filter out events on ServiceNow Instance for easier consolidation and aggregation.
choices.C: Filter out events at source rather than in the ServiceNow instance.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Setting severity to 0 is equals to Clear event
In short, 0 will clear the alert.

Selected Answer: A
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itom-forum/incomming-events-are-missing-value-in-severity-field-how-do-i/m-p/968110

choices.A: In the event rule, set the Severity to 0
choices.B: In the alert rule, set the Severity to 0
choices.D: In the event rule, set the Severity to -1
choices.C: In the alert rule, set the Severity to -1

questions.question_text: For an incoming event with a matching message key, what allows an existing alert to be automatically closed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/task/t_EMResolveCloseIncidentAlert.html

A
Role required: evt_mgmt_admin, evt_mgmt_operator, or evt_mgmt_user

Selected Answer: A
Role required: evt_mgmt_admin, evt_mgmt_operator, OR evt_mgmt_user

Selected Answer: A
the evt_mgmt_user is enough to close alert through incident

Selected Answer: B
Answer is 'B'. Having only evt_mgmt_admin role causes this problem. Agent should also have either evt_mgmt_user or evt_mgmt_operator role as mentioned in document - 
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/task/t_EMResolveCloseIncidentAlert.html
It's D. You need operator to take actions on alerts.

Question is worded erroneously, should be "A support agent resolves an incident associated with an alert, but the alert does NOT automatically close even though the evt_mgmt.incident_closes_alert property is set appropriately to close the alert."

Based on that question, correct answer is A (only evt_mgmt_user is needed).
Changing to A after reading this: https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/task/t_EMResolveCloseIncidentAlert.html
D. The support agent has the evt_mgmt_user role, but not the evt_mgmt_operator role.

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/tokyo-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/reference/r_InstalledWithEventManagement.html

choices.D: The support agent has the evt_mgmt_user role, but not the evt_mgmt_operator role.
choices.B: The support agent only has the evt_mgmt_admin role.
choices.A: The support agent does not have the evt_mgmt_user role.
choices.C: The support agent has the evt_mgmt_operator role, but not the evt_mgmt_user role.

questions.question_text:
A support agent resolves an incident associated with an alert, but the alert does automatically close even though the evt_mgmt.incident_closes_alert property is set appropriately to close the alert.
What is the most likely cause of this issue?
